docs.title: Welcome
docs.text: Hello! I'm LeValle Bradix and welcome to my technical writing portfolio! I'm excited to share the work I've created while learning and growing as a technical communicator. This site showcases my documentation projects, tutorials, and hands-on guides aimed at simplifying complex tools and technologies.

docs.title: What You'll Find Here
docs.text:
• Step-by-step tutorials for tools like MkDocs, GitHub, and more
  • Documentation samples from real-world scenarios and self-driven projects
  • Writing style that emphasizes clarity, structure, and accessibility

docs.title: About Me
docs.text: I transitioned into technical writing from a background in IT and system administration. With a passion for clear communication and user empowerment, I focus on making technical topics easier to understand and apply. I'm especially interested in documentation for open-source tools, system setups, and developer resources.

docs.title: Setting Up MkDocs with Material Theme on Linux Mint
docs.text: A step-by-step guide to creating a professional documentation site using MkDocs and GitHub Pages.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Linux Mint installed
  • GitHub account
  • Terminal access
  • Visual Studio Code
  • Python

docs.title: 1. Install git and github cli
docs.text:
• Open terminal and input: 
    sudo apt update   
sudo apt install git gh      
gh auth login

docs.title: 2. Set up a new mkdocs project
3. Create a virtual environment
docs.text:
1. Open Visual Studio Code
  2. Open new terminal inside Visual Studio Code 
    cd my-new-docs
python3 -m venv venv  
source venv/bin/activate

docs.title: 5. Install mkdocs and the material theme
6. Customize your mkdocs.yml
docs.text:
• Set attributes site_name, theme, palette, font, favicon, and more
  • Find detailed customization information here
  • Add Markdown extension for Visual Studio Code compatibility: 
markdown_extensions:
  - pymdownx.mark

docs.title: 7. Preview your site locally
docs.text: mkdocs serve * View in browser at: http://127.0.0.1:8000

docs.title: 8. Push to github and deploy
docs.text:
git init
git remote add origin https://github.com/<your-username>/my-new-docs.git
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
git push -u origin main
mkdocs gh-deploy

docs.title: 9. Enable github pages
docs.text:
1. Go to repo ⚙ Settings → Pages
  2. Set branch to gh-pages, root folder, and save

    Below is what your GitHub Pages settings should look like:

Done!

Your site should be available at: https://<your-username>.github.io/my-new-docs/
